Art. 4.6. 
Indignity
It is unworthy by law to come to the succession, and, as such, excluded from the succession:
1¡ anyone found guilty of having, as perpetrator, co-perpetrator or accomplice, committed on the person of the deceased, an act resulting in his death, as referred to in articles 376, 393 to 397, 401, 404 and 409, ¤ 4, of the Penal Code, as well as anyone found guilty of having attempted to commit such an act;
2¡ a person who is declared unworthy because he has committed or attempted to commit an act referred to in 1¡, but who, because he has died in the meantime, has not been convicted of that act;
3¡ a person who is declared unworthy because he has been found guilty of having committed, as perpetrator, co-perpetrator or accomplice, on the person of the deceased an act as referred to in articles 375, 398 to 400, 402, 403, 405, 409, ¤¤ 1 to 3 and 5, and 422bis of the Penal Code.
2 The unworthiness referred to in paragraph 1, 1¡ is a civil sanction which produces its effects by the mere fact that the successor has been found guilty.
The unworthiness referred to in paragraph 1, 2¡ is a civil penalty, imposed by the court at the request of the Public Prosecutor.
The disqualification referred to in paragraph 1, 3¡ is a civil penalty that may be imposed by the criminal court if it finds the successor guilty of having committed one of the acts referred to therein. The criminal court may also impose this civil penalty on a person found guilty of having attempted to commit such an act.
